abstract.text: Sends the contents of a URL to a peer.

inlineContent.text: A file or HTTP URL.
A name for the resource.
The peer that should receive this resource.
A block that gets called when delivery succeeds or fails. Upon success, the handler is called with an error value of
. Upon failure, the handle is called with an error object that indicates what went wrong.
An
object that can be used to query the status of the transfer or cancel the transfer.
This method is asynchronous (nonblocking).
On the local device, the completion handler block is called when delivery succeeds or when an error occurs.
On the recipient device, the session calls its delegate’s
method as soon as it begins receiving the resource. This method provides an
object that your app can use to cancel the transfer or check its status.
Upon successful delivery, on the recipient device, the session calls its delegate’s

method. The received resource is written to a file in a temporary location with the same base name; the app is responsible for opening the file or moving it to a permanent location before that delegate method returns.

abstract.text: Support peer-to-peer connectivity and the discovery of nearby devices.
object represents a peer in a multipeer session.
object enables and manages communication among all peers in a Multipeer Connectivity session.
Sends a message to nearby peers.
Sends the contents of a URL to a peer.
Opens a byte stream to a nearby peer.
Indicates that the local peer finished receiving a resource from a nearby peer.
Indicates that the local peer began receiving a resource from a nearby peer.
An object that conveys ongoing progress to the user for a specified task.
A value that identifies the location of a resource, such as an item on a remote server or the path to a local file.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
